entities.description: The Abbasid Caliphate was the third caliphate to succeed the Islamic prophet Muhammad. It was founded by a dynasty descended from Muhammad's uncle, Abbas ibn Abdul-Muttalib, from whom the dynasty takes its name. They ruled as caliphs for most of the caliphate from their capital in Baghdad in modern-day Iraq, after having overthrown the Umayyad Caliphate in the Abbasid Revolution of 750 CE (132 AH)

heading: Deaths
txt: Aldric, bishop of Le Mans

entities.title: Aldric of Le Mans
entities.description: Saint Aldric was Bishop of Le Mans in the time of Louis the Pious.

entities.title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Le Mans
entities.description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Le Mans is a Roman Catholic diocese of France. The diocese is now a suffragan of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Rennes, Dol, and Saint-Malo but had previously been suffragan to Bourges, Paris, Sens, and Tours.

heading: Deaths
txt: Canute Lavard, Danish prince and saint (b. 1096)

entities.title: Canute Lavard
entities.description: Canute Lavard was a Danish prince. Later he was the first Duke of Schleswig and the first border prince who was both a Danish and a German vassal, a position leading towards the historical double position of Southern Jutland. He was killed by his cousin Magnus, who saw him as a rival to the Danish throne. Canute Lavard was canonized in 1170.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles I of Naples (b. 1226)

entities.title: Charles I of Naples
entities.description: Charles I, commonly called Charles of Anjou, was a member of the royal Capetian dynasty and the founder of the second House of Anjou. He was Count of Provence (1246–85) and Forcalquier in the Holy Roman Empire, Count of Anjou and Maine (1246–85) in France; he was also King of Sicily (1266–85) and Prince of Achaea (1278–85). In 1272, he was proclaimed King of Albania; and in 1277 he purchased a cla

heading: Deaths
txt: Denis of Portugal (b. 1261)

entities.title: Denis of Portugal
entities.description: Denis, called the Farmer King and the Poet King, was King of Portugal. The eldest son of Afonso III of Portugal by his second wife, Beatrice of Castile, and grandson of Alfonso X of Castile, Denis succeeded his father in 1279. His marriage to Elizabeth of Aragon, who was later canonised as a saint of the Roman Catholic Church, was arranged in 1281 when she was 10 years old.

heading: Deaths
txt: Inês de Castro, Castilian noblewoman (b. 1325)

entities.title: Inês de Castro
entities.description: Inês de Castro was a Galician noblewoman best known as lover and posthumously-recognized wife of King Peter I of Portugal. The dramatic circumstances of her relationship with Peter, which was forbidden by his father King Afonso IV, her murder at the orders of Afonso, Peter's bloody revenge on her killers, and the legend of the coronation of her exhumed corpse by Peter, have made Inês de Castro a f

heading: Deaths
txt: John Montagu, 3rd Earl of Salisbury, English Earl (b. 1350)

entities.title: John Montagu, 3rd Earl of Salisbury
entities.description: John Montagu, 3rd Earl of Salisbury and 5th and 2nd Baron Montagu, KG was an English nobleman, one of the few who remained loyal to Richard II after Henry IV became king.

heading: Deaths
txt: Amadeus VIII of Savoy a.k.a. Antipope Felix V (b. 1383)

entities.title: Amadeus VIII of Savoy
entities.description: Amadeus VIII was a Savoyard nobleman, the son of Amadeus VII, Count of Savoy and Bonne of Berry. He was surnamed the Peaceful. After the death of his father in 1391, his mother acted as a regent, because of his youth. He was a claimant to the papacy from 1439 to 1449 as Felix V in opposition to Eugene IV and Nicholas V, and is considered the last historical antipope.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Vischer the Elder, German sculptor (b. 1455)

entities.title: Peter Vischer the Elder
entities.description: Peter Vischer the Elder was a German sculptor, the son of Hermann Vischer, and the most notable member of the Vischer Family of Nuremberg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Catherine of Aragon (b. 1485)

entities.title: Catherine of Aragon
entities.description: Catherine of Aragon was Queen of England from June 1509 until May 1533 as the first wife of King Henry VIII; she was previously Princess of Wales as the wife of Henry's elder brother, Arthur.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis de Blois, Flemish monk and author (b. 1506)

entities.title: Louis de Blois
entities.description: Abbot Louis de Blois, O.S.B., was a Flemish monk and mystical writer, generally known under the name of Blosius.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas Hilliard, English painter and goldsmith (b. 1547)

entities.title: Nicholas Hilliard
entities.description: Nicholas Hilliard was an English goldsmith and limner best known for his portrait miniatures of members of the courts of Elizabeth I and James I of England. He mostly painted small oval miniatures, but also some larger cabinet miniatures, up to about ten inches tall, and at least two famous half-length panel portraits of Elizabeth. He enjoyed continuing success as an artist, and continuing financi

heading: Deaths
txt: Ruggiero Giovannelli, Italian composer and author (b. 1560)

entities.title: Ruggiero Giovannelli
entities.description: Ruggiero Giovannelli was an Italian composer of the late Renaissance and early Baroque eras. He was a member of the Roman School, and succeeded Palestrina at St. Peter's.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Innocent X (b. 1574)

entities.title: Pope Innocent X
entities.description: Pope Innocent X, born Giovanni Battista Pamphilj, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 15 September 1644 to his death in 1655.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theophilus Eaton, American farmer and politician, 1st Governor of the New Haven Colony (b. 1590)

entities.title: Theophilus Eaton
entities.description: Theophilus Eaton was a merchant, farmer, and Puritan colonial leader who was the co-founder and first governor of New Haven Colony, Connecticut.

entities.title: List of colonial governors of Connecticut
entities.description: The territory of the United States state of Connecticut was first settled by Europeans in the 1620s, when Dutch traders established trading posts on the Connecticut River. English settlers, mainly Puritans fleeing repression in England, began to arrive in the 1630s, and a number of separate colonies were established. The first was the Saybrook Colony in 1635, based at the mouth of the Connecticut;

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Gerard, 1st Earl of Macclesfield, English general and politician, Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire (b. 1618)

entities.title: Charles Gerard, 1st Earl of Macclesfield
entities.description: Charles Gerard, 1st Earl of Macclesfield, PC was an English aristocrat, soldier and courtier.

entities.title: Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire
entities.description: This is a list of people who have served as Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire. Since 1694, all the Lord Lieutenants have also been Custos Rotulorum of Gloucestershire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Raffaello Fabretti, Italian scholar and author (b. 1618)

entities.title: Raffaello Fabretti
entities.description: Raphael Fabretti was an Italian antiquarian.

heading: Deaths
txt: François Fénelon, French archbishop, theologian, and poet (b. 1651)

entities.title: François Fénelon
entities.description: François de Salignac de la Mothe-Fénelon, more commonly known as François Fénelon, was a French Roman Catholic archbishop, theologian, poet and writer. He today is remembered mostly as the author of The Adventures of Telemachus, first published in 1699.

heading: Deaths
txt: Allan Ramsay, Scottish poet and playwright (b. 1686)

entities.title: Allan Ramsay (poet)
entities.description: Allan Ramsay was a Scottish poet, playwright, publisher, librarian, and impresario of early Enlightenment Edinburgh.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Clap, American minister and academic (b. 1703)

entities.title: Thomas Clap
entities.description: Thomas Clap or Thomas Clapp was an American academic and educator, a Congregational minister, and college administrator. He was both the fifth rector and the earliest official to be called "president" of Yale College (1740–1766). He is best known for his successful reform of Yale in the 1740s, partnering with the Rev. Dr. Samuel Johnson to restructure the forty-year-old institution along more mode

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Gustaf Tessin, Swedish politician and diplomat (b. 1695)

entities.title: Carl Gustaf Tessin
entities.description: Carl Gustaf Tessin was a Swedish Count and politician and son of architect Nicodemus Tessin the Younger and Hedvig Eleonora Stenbock. He was one of the most brilliant personages of his day, and the most prominent representative of French culture in Sweden. He was also a fine orator.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Dennie, American journalist and author (b. 1768)

entities.title: Joseph Dennie
entities.description: Joseph Dennie was an American author and journalist who was one of the foremost men of letters of the Federalist Era. A Federalist, Dennie is best remembered for his series of essays entitled The Lay Preacher and as the founding editor of The Port Folio, a journal espousing classical republican values. Port Folio was the most highly regarded and successful literary publication of its time, and the

heading: Deaths
txt: John Thomas Campbell, Irish-Australian public servant and politician (b. 1770)

entities.title: John Thomas Campbell
entities.description: John Thomas Campbell (1770–1830) was a public servant and politician in the New South Wales Legislative Council during the early Australian colonial period.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Lawrence, English painter and educator (b. 1769)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mustafa Reşid Pasha, Ottoman politician, Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire (b. 1800)

entities.title: Mustafa Reşid Pasha
entities.description: Koca Mustafa Reşid Pasha was an Ottoman statesman and diplomat, known best as the chief architect behind the Ottoman government reforms known as Tanzimat.

entities.title: List of Ottoman Grand Viziers
entities.description: The Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire was the de facto prime minister of the sultan in the Ottoman Empire, with absolute power of attorney and, in principle, dismissible only by the sultan himself in the classical period, before the Tanzimat reforms, or until the 1908 Revolution. He held the imperial seal and could convene all other viziers to attend to affairs of the state in the Imperial Counci

heading: Deaths
txt: Caleb Blood Smith, American journalist and politician, 6th U.S. Secretary of the Interior (b. 1808)

entities.title: Caleb Blood Smith
entities.description: Caleb Blood Smith was a United States Representative from Indiana, the 6th United States Secretary of the Interior and a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the District of Indiana.

entities.title: U.S. Secretary of the Interior
entities.description: The United States secretary of the interior is the head of the United States Department of the Interior. The secretary and the Department of the Interior are responsible for the management and conservation of most federal land and natural resources, leading such agencies as the Bureau of Land Management, the United States Geological Survey, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and the National Park Service.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tewfik Pasha, Egyptian ruler (b. 1852)

entities.title: Tewfik Pasha
entities.description: Mohamed Tewfik Pasha, also known as Tawfiq of Egypt, was khedive of Egypt and the Sudan between 1879 and 1892 and the sixth ruler from the Muhammad Ali Dynasty.

heading: Deaths
txt: Josef Stefan, Slovenian physicist and mathematician (b. 1835)

entities.title: Josef Stefan
entities.description: Josef Stefan was an ethnic Carinthian Slovene physicist, mathematician, and poet of the Austrian Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sophia Jex-Blake, English physician and feminist (b. 1840)

entities.title: Sophia Jex-Blake
entities.description: Sophia Louisa Jex-Blake was an English physician, teacher and feminist. She led the campaign to secure women access to a University education when she and six other women, collectively known as the Edinburgh Seven, began studying medicine at the University of Edinburgh in 1869. She was the first practising female doctor in Scotland, and one of the first in the wider United Kingdom of Great Britain

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Ware Eliot, American businessman and philanthropist, co-founded Washington University in St. Louis (b. 1843)

entities.title: Henry Ware Eliot
entities.description: Henry Ware Eliot was an American industrialist and philanthropist who lived in St. Louis, Missouri. He was the father of poet T. S. Eliot.

entities.title: Washington University in St. Louis
entities.description: Washington University in St. Louis is a private research university in Greater St. Louis with its main campus (Danforth) mostly in unincorporated St. Louis County, Missouri, and Clayton, Missouri. It also has a West Campus in Clayton, North Campus in the West End neighborhood of St. Louis, Missouri, and Medical Campus in the Central West End neighborhood of St. Louis, Missouri.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edmund Barton, Australian judge and politician, 1st Prime Minister of Australia (b. 1849)

entities.title: Edmund Barton
entities.description: Sir Edmund "Toby" Barton, was an Australian politician and judge who served as the first Prime Minister of Australia, in office from 1901 to 1903. He resigned to become a founding member of the High Court of Australia, where he served until his death.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Australia
entities.description: The prime minister of Australia is the head of government of Australia. The prime minister is the leader of the federal government and is also accountable to federal parliament under the principles of responsible government. The incumbent prime minister is Scott Morrison, who took office in August 2018 as leader of the Liberal Party.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolaos Kalogeropoulos, Greek politician, 99th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1851)

entities.title: Nikolaos Kalogeropoulos
entities.description: Nikolaos Kalogeropoulos was a Greek politician and briefly Prime Minister of Greece.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Channing, American historian and author (b. 1856)

entities.title: Edward Channing
entities.description: Edward Perkins Channing was an American historian and an author of a monumental History of the United States in six volumes, for which he won the 1926 Pulitzer Prize for History. His thorough research in printed sources and judicious judgments made the book a standard reference for scholars for decades. Channing taught at Harvard 1883–1929 and trained many PhD's who became professors at major univ

heading: Deaths
txt: André Maginot, French sergeant and politician (b. 1877)

entities.title: André Maginot
entities.description: André Maginot was a French civil servant, soldier, and Member of Parliament. He is best known for his advocacy of the string of forts known as the Maginot Line.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guy d'Hardelot, French pianist and composer (b. 1858)

entities.title: Guy d'Hardelot
entities.description: Guy d'Hardelot was the pen name of Helen Rhodes, a French composer, pianist, and teacher.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Finger, English journalist and author (b. 1869)

entities.title: Charles Finger
entities.description: Charles Joseph Finger was a British born American writer. He also directed an orchestra and taught piano.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikola Tesla, Serbian-American physicist and engineer (b. 1856)

entities.title: Nikola Tesla
entities.description: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system.

heading: Deaths
txt: René Guénon, French-Egyptian philosopher and author (b. 1886)

entities.title: René Guénon
entities.description: René-Jean-Marie-Joseph Guénon, also known as Abd al-Wahid Yahya, was a French author and intellectual who remains an influential figure in the domain of metaphysics having written on topics ranging from "sacred science", to symbolism and initiation.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers, English tennis player and coach (b. 1878)

entities.title: Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers
entities.description: Dorothea Lambert Chambers was a British tennis player. She won seven Wimbledon Women's Singles titles and a gold medal at the 1908 Summer Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Edward Moore, New Zealand-Australian farmer and politician, 23rd Premier of Queensland (b. 1876)

entities.title: Arthur Edward Moore
entities.description: Arthur Edward Moore was an Australian politician. He was the Country and Progressive National Party Premier of Queensland, from 1929 to 1932. He was the only Queensland Premier not to come from the ranks of the Labor Party between 1915 and 1957. Although successful in achieving the unity of the conservative forces in Queensland for an extended period, Moore's abilities were tested by the onset of

entities.title: Premier of Queensland
entities.description: The Premier of Queensland is the head of government in the Australian state of Queensland.

heading: Deaths
txt: Reg Parnell, English racing driver and manager (b. 1911)

entities.title: Reg Parnell
entities.description: Reginald Parnell was a racing driver and team manager from Derby, England. He participated in seven Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, achieving one podium, and scoring a total of nine championship points.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Goodis, American author and screenwriter (b. 1917)

entities.title: David Goodis
entities.description: David Loeb Goodis was an American writer of crime fiction noted for his output of short stories and novels in the noir fiction genre. Born in Philadelphia, Goodis alternately resided there and in New York City and Hollywood during his professional years. According to critic Dennis Drabelle, "Despite his [university] education, a combination of ethnicity (Jewish) and temperament allowed him to empa

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Schuricht, German-Swiss conductor (b. 1880)

heading: Deaths
txt: J. L. B. Smith, South African chemist and academic (b. 1897)

entities.title: J. L. B. Smith
entities.description: James Leonard Brierley Smith, known more commonly as "J. L. B. Smith",, was a South African ichthyologist, organic chemist, and university professor. He was the first to identify a taxidermied fish as a coelacanth, at the time thought to be long extinct.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Berryman, American poet and scholar (b. 1914)

entities.title: John Berryman
entities.description: John Allyn McAlpin Berryman was an American poet and scholar. He was a major figure in American poetry in the second half of the 20th century and is considered a key figure in the "confessional" school of poetry. His best-known work is The Dream Songs.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alvar Lidell, English journalist and radio announcer(b. 1908)

entities.title: Alvar Lidell
entities.description: Tord Alvar Quan Lidell MBE was a BBC radio announcer and newsreader. During the Second World War his distinctive voice became synonymous with the reading of news.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric Robinson, Australian businessman and politician, 2nd Australian Minister for Finance (b. 1926)

entities.title: Minister for Finance (Australia)
entities.description: The Minister for Finance in the Government of Australia is responsible for monitoring government expenditure and financial management. The current minister is Senator Simon Birmingham, who has held the position since October 2020.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Kastler, German-French physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1902)

entities.title: Alfred Kastler
entities.description: Alfred Kastler was a French physicist, and Nobel Prize laureate.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Juan Rulfo, Mexican author, screenwriter, and photographer (b. 1917))

entities.title: Juan Rulfo
entities.description: Juan Nepomuceno Carlos Pérez Rulfo Vizcaíno, best known as Juan Rulfo, was a Mexican writer, screenwriter and photographer. He is best known for two literary works, the 1955 novel Pedro Páramo, and the collection of short stories El Llano en llamas (1953). This collection includes the popular tale "¡Diles que no me maten!".

heading: Deaths
txt: Zara Cisco Brough, American Nipmuc Indian chief and fashion designer (b.1919)

entities.title: Zara Cisco Brough
entities.description: Zara Cisco Brough, often spelled as Zara Ciscoe Brough, commonly referred to as Princess White Flower, served as the Chief of the Nipmuc Native Indian Tribe for 25 years from 1962 until 1987. She is best known for her work to preserve Nipmuc heritage, especially her letter of intention to petition for federal recognition of the Nipmuc as a legally distinct Native American people, which resulted in

entities.title: Nipmuc
entities.description: The Nipmuc or Nipmuck people are descendants of the indigenous Algonquian peoples of Nippenet, 'the freshwater pond place', which corresponds to central Massachusetts and immediately adjacent portions of Connecticut and Rhode Island. The English had their first encounter with members of the tribe in 1630, when John Acquittamaug (Nipmuc) took maize to sell to the starving colonists of Boston.

heading: Deaths
txt: Trevor Howard, English actor (b. 1913)

heading: Deaths
txt: Hirohito, Japanese emperor (b. 1901)

entities.title: Hirohito
entities.description: Emperor Shōwa , better known in English by his personal name Hirohito (裕仁), was the 124th emperor of Japan according to the traditional order of succession, ruling over the Empire of Japan from 25 December 1926 until 2 May 1947, after which he was Emperor of the state of Japan until his death. He was succeeded by his fifth child and eldest son, Akihito. Hirohito and his wife, Empress Kōjun, had se

heading: Deaths
txt: Bronko Nagurski, Canadian-American football player and wrestler (b. 1908)

entities.title: Bronko Nagurski
entities.description: Bronislau "Bronko" Nagurski was a Canadian-American professional American football player in the National Football League (NFL), renowned for his strength and size. Nagurski was also a successful professional wrestler, recognized as a multiple-time World Heavyweight Champion.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Hunt, American puppeteer and voice actor (b. 1951)

entities.title: Richard Hunt (puppeteer)
entities.description: Richard Hunt was an American puppeteer, best known as a Muppet performer on Sesame Street, The Muppet Show, Fraggle Rock, and other projects for The Jim Henson Company. His roles on The Muppet Show included Scooter, Statler, Janice, Beaker and Sweetums.

heading: Deaths
txt: Murray Rothbard, American economist, historian, and theorist (b. 1926)

entities.title: Murray Rothbard
entities.description: Murray Newton Rothbard was an American heterodox economist of the Austrian School, economic historian and political theorist. Rothbard was the founder and leading theoretician of anarcho-capitalism, a staunch advocate of historical revisionism and a central figure in the 20th-century American libertarian movement. He wrote over twenty books on political theory, revisionist history, economics, and

heading: Deaths
txt: Károly Grósz, Hungarian politician, 51st Prime Minister of Hungary (b. 1930)

entities.title: Károly Grósz
entities.description: Károly Grósz [ˈkaːroj ˈɡroːs] was a Hungarian communist politician, who served as the General Secretary of the Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party from 1988 to 1989.

entities.title: List of Prime Ministers of Hungary
entities.description: The following is a list of prime ministers of Hungary from when the first Prime Minister, Lajos Batthyány, took office in 1848 until the present day. The prime minister is head of the Government of Hungary. On 30 November 2020, Viktor Orbán became the longest serving prime minister in this modern era.

heading: Deaths
txt: Owen Bradley, American record producer (b. 1915)

entities.title: Owen Bradley
entities.description: William Owen Bradley was an American musician and record producer who, along with Chet Atkins, Bob Ferguson, Bill Porter, and Don Law, was one of the chief architects of the 1950s and 1960s Nashville sound in country music and rockabilly.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vladimir Prelog, Croatian-Swiss chemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1906)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded annually by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences to scientists in the various fields of chemistry. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895, awarded for outstanding contributions in chemistry, physics, literature, peace, and physiology or medicine. This award is administered by the Nobel Foundation, and awarded by t

heading: Deaths
txt: Gary Albright, American wrestler (b. 1963)

entities.title: Gary Albright
entities.description: Gary Albright was an American professional wrestler best known for his work in Japan, first with UWF International (UWFi), and later All Japan Pro Wrestling (AJPW). In AJPW, Albright was a two time World Tag Team Champion. Albright was also known for his work with Stampede Wrestling in Canada, under his birth name as well as the ring name Vokhan Singh.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Carr, American singer (b. 1942)

entities.title: James Carr (musician)
entities.description: James Edward Carr was an American R&B and soul singer, described as "one of the greatest pure vocalists that deep Southern soul ever produced."

heading: Deaths
txt: Avery Schreiber, American comedian and actor (b. 1935)

entities.title: Avery Schreiber
entities.description: Avery Lawrence Schreiber was an American actor and comedian. He was a veteran of stage, television, and movies who came to prominence in the 1960s in a comedy duo with Jack Burns. He acted in an array of acting roles mostly on television sitcoms and a series of popular advertisements for Doritos tortilla chips.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ingrid Thulin, Swedish actress (b. 1926)

entities.title: Ingrid Thulin
entities.description: Ingrid Lilian Thulin was a Swedish film actress.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre Daninos, French author (b. 1913)

entities.title: Pierre Daninos
entities.description: Pierre Daninos was a French writer and humorist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heinrich Harrer, Austrian mountaineer, geographer, and author (b. 1912)

entities.title: Heinrich Harrer
entities.description: Heinrich Harrer was an Austrian mountaineer, sportsman, geographer, and author. He was a member of the four-man climbing team that made the first ascent of the North Face of the Eiger, the "last problem" of the Alps. He wrote the books Seven Years in Tibet (1952) and The White Spider (1959).

heading: Deaths
txt: Bobby Hamilton, American race car driver and businessman (b. 1957)

entities.title: Bobby Hamilton
entities.description: Charles Robert Hamilton Sr. was an American stock car racing driver. A driver and owner in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series circuit and the winner of the 2004 NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series championship, Hamilton owned Bobby Hamilton Racing. Hamilton's son, Bobby Hamilton Jr., is also a NASCAR driver.

heading: Deaths
txt: Magnus Magnusson, Icelandic journalist, author, and academic (b. 1929)

heading: Deaths
txt: Alwyn Schlebusch, South African academic and politician, Vice State President of South Africa (b. 1917)

entities.title: Alwyn Schlebusch
entities.description: Alwyn Louis Schlebusch was a South African politician, the only holder of the title Vice State President of South Africa from 1 January 1981 to 14 September 1984. He was an Afrikaner with a surname of German origin. He was born in Lady Grey, Eastern Cape. He was the son of Charel Johannes Schlebusch and Elizabeth Cornelia Myburgh.

entities.title: Vice State President of South Africa
entities.description: The Vice State President of South Africa was a position established between 1981 and 1984. Alwyn Schlebusch was the only holder of the position.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tony Blankley, British-born American child actor, journalist and pundit (b. 1948)

entities.title: Tony Blankley
entities.description: Anthony David "Tony" Blankley was an American political analyst who gained fame as the press secretary for Newt Gingrich, the first Republican Speaker of the House in forty years, and as a regular panelist on The McLaughlin Group. He later became an Executive Vice President with Edelman public relations in Washington, D.C. He was a Visiting Senior Fellow in National-Security Communications at the

heading: Deaths
txt: Run Run Shaw, Chinese-Hong Kong businessman and philanthropist, founded Shaw Brothers Studio and TVB (b. 1907)

entities.title: Run Run Shaw
entities.description: Sir Run Run Shaw, also known as Shao Yifu and Siu Yat-fu, was a Hong Kong entertainment mogul and philanthropist. He was one of the most influential figures in the Asian entertainment industry. He founded the Shaw Brothers Studio, one of the largest film production companies in Hong Kong, and TVB, the dominant television company in Hong Kong.

entities.title: Shaw Brothers Studio
entities.description: Shaw Brothers (HK) Ltd. is the largest film production company of Hong Kong that operated from 1925 to 2011.

entities.title: TVB
entities.description: Television Broadcasts Limited (TVB) is a television broadcasting company based in Hong Kong. The company operates five free-to-air terrestrial television channels in Hong Kong, with TVB Jade as its main Cantonese language service, and TVB Pearl as its main English service. TVB is headquartered at TVB City at the Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mompati Merafhe, Botswana general and politician, Vice-President of Botswana (b. 1936)

entities.title: Mompati Merafhe
entities.description: Mompati Sebogodi Merafhe was a Botswana politician who was Vice-President of Botswana from 2008 to 2012. He was a retired Lieutenant-General and served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1994 to 2008.

entities.title: Vice-President of Botswana
entities.description:
The Vice-President of Botswana is the second-highest executive official in the Government of Botswana. 
Vice-President is appointed by the President of Botswana among elected members of the National Assembly. Vice-President is the constitutional successor of the President in case of a vacancy. The current Vice President is Slumber Tsogwane.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Minister of Home Affairs (India)
entities.description: The Minister of Home Affairs is the head of the Ministry of Home Affairs of the Government of India. One of the senior-most officers in the Union Cabinet, the chief responsibility of the Home Minister is the maintenance of India's internal security; the country's large police force comes under its jurisdiction. heading: Deaths
txt: Mário Soares, Portuguese politician; 16th President of Portugal (b. 1924)

entities.title: Mário Soares
entities.description: Mário Alberto Nobre Lopes Soares, GColTE, GCC, GColL was a Portuguese politician, who served as Prime Minister of Portugal from 1976 to 1978 and from 1983 to 1985, and subsequently as the 17th President of Portugal from 1986 to 1996. He was the first Secretary-General of the Socialist Party, from its foundation in 1973 to 1986.

entities.title: President of Portugal
entities.description: The president of the Portuguese Republic is the executive head of state of Portugal. The powers, functions and duties of prior presidential offices, and their relation with the prime minister and cabinets have over time differed with the various Portuguese constitutions.

entities.title: 2021 storming of the United States Capitol
entities.description: On January 6, 2021, the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C., was stormed during a riot and violent attack against the U.S. Congress. A mob of supporters of President Donald Trump attempted to overturn his defeat in the 2020 presidential election by disrupting the joint session of Congress assembled to count electoral votes to formalize Joe Biden's victory.
